newsitem.title: GERMANY: Daimler,AT&T to bid for German phone licence-report.
newsitem.headline: Daimler,AT&T to bid for German phone licence-report.

text.p: AT&T Corp and the Debis unit of Daimler-Benz AG are planning to form a consortium to bid for the E2 cellular phone licence in Germany, a weekly magazine said on Wednesday.
According to a report in the Wirtschafts Woche business magazine, Debis, AT&T and its European partner Unisource NV are working together on a bid for the licence, which will be awarded next year.
AT&T was not immediately available for comment and a spokesman for Debis called the report speculation.
"We do not commment on speculation," he told Reuters.
The report was released ahead of publication on Friday.
Industry observers have long thought it likely that Debis would make a bold step into the telecoms arena ahead of liberalisation of the sector in 1998.
Although it does not operate a network of its own, Debis's Debitel unit is Germany's biggest mobile telephone service provider with some 700,000 customers under contract.
AT&T and Unisource, an alliance of telecommunications companies from Sweden, Spain, Switzerland and the Netherlands, are also forming a fixed-wire network venture with Mannesmann .
They will jointly buy a stake in DBKom GmbH, the communications subsidiary of railway Deutsche Bahn AG.
The magazine report said the fact that AT&T was teaming up with Daimler was bad news for utilities Viag AG and RWE AG.
Those companies are forming an alliance with British Telecom and hope to win the E2 licence.
